paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-vi
paragraph.content: The total payment amount needed to bring the account current; and

paragraph.label: 1026-34-b
paragraph.title: Prohibited acts or practices for dwelling-secured loans; open-end credit.
paragraph.content: Prohibited <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">acts</ref> or practices for <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>-secured loans; <ref target="1026-2-a-20" reftype="term">open-end credit</ref>. In connection with <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> that does not meet the definition in § <ref target="1026-2-a-20" reftype="internal">1026.2(a)(20)</ref>, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> shall not structure a home-secured loan as an open-end plan to evade the requirements of § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a
paragraph.title: Prohibited acts or practices for high-cost mortgages.
paragraph.content: Prohibited <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">acts</ref> or practices for high-cost mortgages. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> extending mortgage <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> shall not:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-1
paragraph.title: Home improvement contracts.
paragraph.content: Home improvement contracts. Pay a contractor under a home improvement contract from the proceeds of a mortgage covered by § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-1-i
paragraph.content: By an instrument payable to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> or jointly to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> and the contractor; or

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: At the election of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, through a third-party escrow agent in accordance with terms established in a written agreement signed by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, and the contractor prior to the disbursement.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-2
paragraph.title: Notice to assignee.
paragraph.content: Notice to assignee. Sell or otherwise assign a mortgage subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> without furnishing the following statement to the purchaser or assignee: “Notice: This is a mortgage subject to special rules under the Federal Truth in Lending <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref>. Purchasers or assignees of this mortgage could be liable for all claims and defenses with respect to the mortgage that the borrower could assert against the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.”

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-3
paragraph.title: Refinancings within one-year period.
paragraph.content: Refinancings within one-year period. Within one year of having extended <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>, refinance any loan subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> to the same borrower into another loan subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>, unless the refinancing is in the borrower's interest. An assignee holding or servicing an extension of mortgage <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>, shall not, for the remainder of the one-year period following the date of origination of the <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref>, refinance any loan subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> to the same borrower into another loan subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref>, unless the refinancing is in the borrower's interest. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> (or assignee) is prohibited from engaging in <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">acts</ref> or practices to evade this provision, including a pattern or practice of arranging for the refinancing of its own loans by affiliated or unaffiliated <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref>, or modifying a loan agreement (whether or not the existing loan is satisfied and replaced by the new loan) and charging a fee.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. Extend <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> based on the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s collateral without regard to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, including the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current and reasonably expected income, employment, assets other than the collateral, current obligations, and mortgage-related obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-i
paragraph.title: Mortgage-related obligations.
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref>, mortgage-related obligations are expected property taxes, premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> as set forth in § <ref target="1026-35-b-3-i" reftype="internal">1026.35(b), and </ref>similar expenses.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii
paragraph.title: Verification of repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Verification of repayment ability. Under this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as follows:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify amounts of income or assets that it relies on to determine repayment ability, including expected income or assets, by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s Internal Revenue Service Form W-2, tax returns, payroll receipts, financial institution records, or other third-party documents that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii-A" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)(A)</ref>, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> has not violated paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)</ref> if the amounts of income and assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relied upon in determining repayment ability are not materially greater than the amounts of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> could have verified pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii-A" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)(A)</ref> at the time the loan was consummated.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> is presumed to have complied with this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> with respect to a transaction if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Verifies the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Determines the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability using the largest payment of principal and interest scheduled in the first seven years following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> and taking into account current obligations and mortgage-related obligations as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-i" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(i)</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: Assesses the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability taking into account at least one of the following: The ratio of total debt obligations to income, or the income the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have after paying debt obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv
paragraph.title: Exclusions from presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Exclusions from presumption of compliance. Notwithstanding the previous paragraph, no presumption of compliance is available for a transaction for which:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-A
paragraph.content: The regular periodic payments for the first seven years would cause the principal balance to increase; or

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan is less than seven years and the regular periodic payments when aggregated do not fully amortize the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-v
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. This paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> does not apply to temporary or “bridge” loans with terms of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> plans to sell a current <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> within twelve months.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Partial payments. The disclosure of any partial payments received since the previous statement that were sent to a suspense or unapplied funds account as required by § 1026.41(d)(3)(i) should reflect any funds that were received in the time period covered by the current statement and that were placed in such account. The disclosure of any portion of payments since the beginning of the calendar year that was sent to a partial payment or suspense account as required by § 1026.41(d)(3)(ii) should reflect all funds that are currently held in a suspense or unapplied funds account. For example:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Suppose a payment of $1,000 is due, but the consumer sends in only $600 on January 1, which is held in a suspense account. Further assume there are no fees charged on this account. Assuming there are no other funds in the suspense account, the January statement should reflect: Unapplied funds since last statement—$600. Unapplied funds YTD—$600.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Assume the same facts as in the preceding paragraph, except that during February the consumer sends in $300 and this too is held in the suspense account. The statement should reflect: Unapplied funds since last statement—$300. Unapplied funds YTD—$900.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-Interp-1-iii
interpParagraph.content: Assume the same facts as in the preceding paragraph, except that during March the consumer sends in $400. Of this payment, $100 completes a full periodic payment when added to the $900 in funds already held in the suspense account. This $1,000 is applied to the January payment, and the remaining $300 remains in the suspense account. The statement should reflect: Unapplied funds since last statement—$300. Unapplied Funds YTD—$300.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Return the partial payment to the consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-b-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Courtesy period. The meaning of “courtesy period” is explained in comment 7(b)(11)-1.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-b-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Reasonably prompt time. Section 1026.41(b) requires that the periodic statement be delivered or placed in the mail no later than a reasonably prompt time after the payment due date or the end of any courtesy period. Delivering, emailing or placing the periodic statement in the mail within four days of close of the courtesy period of the previous billing cycle generally would be considered reasonably prompt.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-iii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, calculated in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-5" reftype="internal">(c)(5)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-8-iv
paragraph.content: A notice indicating any loss mitigation program to which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has agreed, if applicable;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv
paragraph.content: For which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> underwrites the loan, taking into account the monthly payment for <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref>, using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: Periodic payments of principal and interest that will repay either:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The outstanding principal balance over the remaining term of the loan as of the date the interest rate adjusts to the maximum interest rate set forth in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iv-A" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(iv)(A)</ref> of this section, assuming the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have made all required payments as due prior to that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> over the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: For which the <ref target="1026-43-b-6" reftype="term">loan term</ref> does not exceed 30 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4
paragraph.title: Small servicers.
paragraph.content: Small servicers.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-i
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, assignee, or servicer is exempt from the requirements of this section for mortgage loans serviced by a small servicer.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Small servicer defined.
paragraph.content: Small servicer defined. A small servicer is a servicer that either:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: Services 5,000 or fewer mortgage loans, for all of which the servicer (or an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref>) is the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or assignee; or

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Is a Housing Finance Agency, as defined in <ref target="CFR:24-266-5" reftype="external">24 CFR 266.5</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii
paragraph.title: Small servicer determination.
paragraph.content: Small servicer determination. In determining whether a small servicer services 5,000 or fewer mortgage loans, a servicer is evaluated based on the number of mortgage loans serviced by the servicer and any <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliates</ref> as of January 1 for the remainder of the calendar year. A servicer that crosses the threshold will have six months after crossing the threshold or until the next January 1, whichever is later, to comply with any requirements for which a servicer is no longer exempt as a small servicer.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3
paragraph.title: Coupon books.
paragraph.content: Coupon books. The requirements of paragraph <ref target="1026-41-a" reftype="internal">(a)</ref> of this section do not apply to fixed-rate loans if the servicer:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-i
paragraph.content: Provides the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a coupon book that includes on each coupon the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-1" reftype="internal">(d)(1)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii
paragraph.content: Provides the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a coupon book that includes anywhere in the coupon book:

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-A
paragraph.content: The account information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-7" reftype="internal">(d)(7)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: The contact information for the servicer, listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-6" reftype="internal">(d)(6)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-C
paragraph.content: Information on how the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can obtain the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-e-3-iii" reftype="internal">(e)(3)(iii)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-iii
paragraph.content: Makes available upon request to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> by telephone, in writing, in <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>, or electronically, if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> consents, the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-2" reftype="internal">(d)(2)</ref> through <ref target="1026-41-d-5" reftype="internal">(5)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-iv
paragraph.content: Provides the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-8" reftype="internal">(d)(8)</ref> of this section in writing, for any <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> during which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is more than 45 days delinquent.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-2
paragraph.title: Timeshare plans.
paragraph.content: Timeshare plans. Transactions secured by <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref>' interests in timeshare plans, as defined by <ref target="USC:11-101" reftype="external">11 U.S.C. 101</ref>(53D), are exempt from the requirements of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after the date on which the first regular periodic payment will be due; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-ii
paragraph.content: The monthly payment for the standard mortgage is materially lower than the monthly payment for the non-standard mortgage, as calculated under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-5" reftype="internal">(d)(5)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-ii
paragraph.content: The current interest rate in effect for the mortgage loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iii
paragraph.content: An <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref><ref target="1026-36-d-1" reftype="internal">oan or</ref>iginator may receive, and a <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> may pay to an <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref><ref target="1026-36-d-2" reftype="internal">dual l</ref>oan originator, <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> in the form of a contribution to a defined contribution plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan or a benefit under a defined benefit plan that is a designated tax-advantaged plan. In the case of a contribution to a defined contribution plan, the contribution shall not be directly or indirectly based on the terms of that <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref>'s transactions. As used in this paragraph (d)(1)(iii), “designated tax-advantaged plan” means any plan that meets the requirements of Internal Revenue Code section 401(a), 26 U.S.C. 401(a); employee annuity plan described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(a), 26 U.S.C. 403(a); simple retirement account, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 408(p), 26 U.S.C. 408(p); simplified employee pension described in Internal Revenue Code section 408(k), 26 U.S.C. 408(k); annuity contract described in Internal Revenue Code section 403(b), 26 U.S.C. 403(b); or eligible deferred <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> plan, as defined in Internal Revenue Code section 457(b), 26 U.S.C. 457(b).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalty
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalty —

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6-i
paragraph.title: Closed-end credit transactions.
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">Closed-end credit</ref> transactions. For a <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">closed-end credit</ref> transaction, prepayment penalty means a charge imposed for paying all or part of the transaction's principal before the date on which the principal is due, other than a waived, bona fide third-party charge that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> imposes if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> prepays all of the transaction's principal sooner than 36 months after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, provided, however, that interest charged consistent with the monthly interest accrual amortization method is not a prepayment penalty for extensions of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> insured by the Federal Housing Administration that are consummated before January 21, 2015.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-6-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-7-iv
paragraph.content: The existence of any prepayment penalty, as defined in § <ref target="1026-32-b-6-i" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(6)(i)</ref>, that may be charged;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-ii
paragraph.content: A temporary or “bridge” loan with a term of 12 months or less, such as a loan to finance the purchase of a new <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> plans to sell a current <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> within 12 months or a loan to finance the initial construction of a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-iii
paragraph.content: A construction phase of 12 months or less of a construction-to-permanent loan.

appendixSection.label: 1026-H-30(B)
appendixSection.subject: H-30(B) Sample Form of Periodic Statement with Delinquency Box

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-iv
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has made no more than one payment more than 30 days late on the non-standard mortgage during the 12 months immediately preceding the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>'s receipt of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s written application for the standard mortgage.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Partial payments. If a partial payment is sent to a suspense or unapplied funds account, this fact must be in the transaction description along with the date and amount of the payment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Description of late fees. The description of any late fee charges includes the date of the late fee, the amount of the late fee, and the fact that a late fee was imposed.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Meaning. Transaction activity includes any transaction that credits or debits the amount currently due. This is the same amount that is required to be disclosure under § 1026.41(d)(1)(iii). Examples of such transactions include, without limitation:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Payments received and applied;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Payments received and held in a suspense account;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-1-iii
interpParagraph.content: The imposition of any fees (for example late fees); and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-4-Interp-1-iv
interpParagraph.content: The imposition of any charges (for example, private mortgage insurance).

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-A
paragraph.content: The account information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-7" reftype="internal">(d)(7)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-a-2
paragraph.title: Periodic statements.
paragraph.content: Periodic statements. A servicer of a transaction subject to this section shall provide the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, for each <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>, a periodic statement meeting the requirements of paragraphs <ref target="1026-41-b" reftype="internal">(b)</ref>, <ref target="1026-41-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-41-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref> of this section. If a mortgage loan has a <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> shorter than a period of 31 days (for example, a bi-weekly <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>), a periodic statement covering an entire month may be used. For the purposes of this section, servicer includes the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, assignee, or servicer, as applicable. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or assignee that does not currently own the mortgage loan or the mortgage servicing rights is not subject to the requirement in this section to provide a periodic statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-C
paragraph.content: Information on how the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can obtain the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-e-3-iii" reftype="internal">(e)(3)(iii)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-ii-B
paragraph.content: The contact information for the servicer, listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-6" reftype="internal">(d)(6)</ref> of this section; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Master servicing and subservicing. Both a master servicer and a subservicer, as those terms are defined in 12 CFR 1024.31, must meet the requirements of a small servicer. For example, if a master servicer meets the definition of a small servicer, but retains a subservicer that does not meet the definition of a small servicer, the subservicer is not a small servicer for the purposes of determining any exemption, and must comply with the requirements of a servicer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Small servicers that do not qualify for the exemption. A servicer that services any mortgage loans for which a servicer or an affiliate is not the creditor or assignee is not a small servicer. For example, a servicer that owns mortgage servicing rights for mortgage loans that are not owned by the servicer or an affiliate, or for which the servicer or an affiliate was not the entity to whom the obligation was initially payable, is not a small servicer.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-4-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-i
paragraph.content: Provides the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a coupon book that includes on each coupon the information listed in paragraph <ref target="1026-41-d-1" reftype="internal">(d)(1)</ref> of this section;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-iv
interpParagraph.content: Renewable balloon-payment instruments; and

paragraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-i
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, assignee, or servicer is exempt from the requirements of this section for mortgage loans serviced by a small servicer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Handling of partial payments. If a servicer receives a partial payment from a consumer, to the extent not prohibited by applicable law or the legal obligation between the parties, the servicer may take any of the following actions:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Credit the partial payment upon receipt.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Return the partial payment to the consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1-iii
interpParagraph.content: Hold the payment in a suspense or unapplied funds account. If the payment is held in a suspense or unapplied funds account, this fact must be reflected on future periodic statements, in accordance with § 1026.41(d)(3). When sufficient funds accumulate to cover a periodic payment, as defined in § 1026.36(c)(1)(i), they must be treated as a periodic payment received in accordance with § 1026.36(c)(1)(i).

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii
paragraph.title: Standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Standard mortgage. The term standard mortgage means a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: That provides for regular periodic payments that do not:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: Cause the principal balance to increase;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: Allow the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> to defer repayment of principal; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-A-3
paragraph.content: Result in a balloon payment, as defined in § <ref target="1026-18-s-5-i" reftype="internal">1026.18(s)(5)(i)</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: For which the total <ref target="1026-43-b-9" reftype="term">points and fees</ref> payable in connection with the transaction do not exceed the amounts specified in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-3" reftype="internal">(e)(3)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-C
paragraph.content: For which the term does not exceed 40 years;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-D
paragraph.content: For which the interest rate is fixed for at least the first five years after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E
paragraph.content: For which the proceeds from the loan are used solely for the following purposes:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-1
paragraph.content: To pay off the outstanding principal balance on the non-standard mortgage; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-1-ii-E-2
paragraph.content: To pay closing or settlement charges required to be disclosed under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref>, <ref target="USC:12-2601" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 2601</ref> et seq.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Price-level adjusted or other indexed mortgages that have a fixed rate of interest but provide for periodic adjustments to payments and the loan balance to reflect changes in an index measuring prices or inflation;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: A servicer that begins servicing more than 5,000 mortgage loans on October 1, and services more than 5,000 mortgage loans as of January 1 of the following year, would no longer be considered a small servicer on April 1 of that following year.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-H-Interp-7-i
interpParagraph.content: Model H-4(D)(1) illustrates the interest rate adjustment notice required under § 1026.20(c) and Model H-4(D)(2) provides an example of a notice of interest rate adjustment with corresponding payment change. Model H-4(D)(3) illustrates the interest rate adjustment notice required under § 1026.20(d) and Model H-4(D)(4) provides an example of a notice of initial interest rate adjustment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-19-b-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Other variable-rate regulations. Transactions in which the creditor is required to comply with and has complied with the disclosure requirements of the variable-rate regulations of other Federal agencies are exempt from the requirements of § 1026.19(b), by virtue of § 1026.19(d). The exception is also available to creditorsrs that are required by Statete law to comply with the Federal variable-rate regulations noted above. Creditors using this exception should comply with the timing requirements of those regulations rather than the timing requirements of Regulation Z in making the variable-rate disclosures.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: The type and amount of any adjustment to the index, including any margin and an explanation that the margin is the addition of a certain number of percentage points to the index.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: The specific index or formula used in making interest rate adjustments and a source of information about the index or formula; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i
interpParagraph.content: General. For purposes of § 1026.36, compensation is defined in § 1026.36(a)(3) as salaries, commissions, and any financial or similar incentive. For example, the term “compensation” includes:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i-A
interpParagraph.content: An annual or other periodic bonus; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-a-Interp-5-i-B
interpParagraph.content: Awards of merchandise, services, trips, or similar prizes.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Date of the disclosure. The date that must appear on the disclosure is the date the creditor, assignee, or servicer generates the notice to be provided to the consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-A-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Current and new interest rates. The current interest rate is the interest rate that applies on the date of the disclosure. The new interest rate is the interest rate used to calculate the new payment and may be an estimate pursuant to § 1026.20(d)(2). The new payment, if calculated from an estimated new interest rate, will also be an estimate. The “new interest rate” has the same meaning as the “adjusted interest rate.” The requirements of § 1026.20(d)(2)(iii)(A) do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from rounding the interest rate, pursuant to the requirements of the ARM contract.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-v-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Rate limits and foregone interest rate increases. Interest rate carryover, or foregone interest rate increases, is the amount of interest rate increase foregone at the first ARM interest rate adjustment that, subject to rate caps, can be added to future interest rate adjustments to increase, or to offset decreases in, the rate determined by using the index or formula. The disclosures required by § 1026.20(d)(2)(v) regarding foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-viii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Prepayment penalty. The creditor, assignee, or servicer of an ARM with no prepayment penalty, as that term is used in § 1026.20(d)(2)(viii), may decide to exclude the prepayment section from the § 1026.20(d) disclosure, retain the prepayment section and insert after the heading “None” or other indication that there is no prepayment penalty, or indicate there is no prepayment penalty in some other manner. See also comment to Appendices G and H—Open-End and Closed-End Model Forms and Clauses—1.vi.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-v
interpParagraph.content: Preferred-rate loans.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-f-2
paragraph.content: Ensure that each <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref> who works for the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-iii" reftype="term">loan originator organization</ref> is licensed or registered to the extent the individual is required to be licensed or registered under the SAFE <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref>, its implementing regulations, and <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> SAFE <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> implementing law before the individual <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">acts</ref> as a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> in a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-i
paragraph.content: Periodic payments. No servicer shall fail to <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> a periodic payment to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s loan account as of the date of receipt, except when a delay in crediting does not result in any charge to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> or in the reporting of negative information to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> reporti<ref target="1026-36-c-2" reftype="internal">ng age</ref>ncy, or except as provided in paragraph (c)(1)(iii) of this section. A periodic payment, as used in this paragraph (c), is an amount sufficient to cover principal, interest, and escrow (if applicable) for a given <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. A payment qualifies as a periodic payment even if it does not include amounts required to cover late fees, other fees, or non-escrow payments a servicer has advanced on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s behalf.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: Shared-equity or shared-appreciation mortgages;

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-i
paragraph.content: The payment due date;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-6-i
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref>, by following paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-5" reftype="internal">(c)(5)</ref>of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-iii
paragraph.content: Non-conforming payments. If a servicer specifies in writing requirements for the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> to follow in making payments, but accepts a payment that does not conform to the requirements, the servicer shall <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> the payment as of five days after receipt.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-1-ii
paragraph.content: The amount of any late payment fee, and the date on which that fee will be imposed if payment has not been received; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i
paragraph.title: General rule.
paragraph.content: General rule. Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-5-ii" reftype="internal">(c)(5)(ii)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must make the consideration required under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-2-iii" reftype="internal">(c)(2)(iii)</ref> of this section using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-3" reftype="term">fully indexed rate</ref> or any introductory interest rate, whichever is greater; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-5-i-B
paragraph.content: Monthly, <ref target="1026-43-b-2" reftype="term">fully amortizing payments</ref> that are substantially equal.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-2-iii
paragraph.content: Any payment amount past due.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-c-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Clear and conspicuous standard. The “clear and conspicuous” standard generally requires that disclosures be in a reasonably understandable form. Except where otherwise provided, the standard does not prohibit adding to the required disclosures, as long as the additional information does not overwhelm or obscure the required disclosures. For example, while certain information about the escrow account (such as the account balance) is not required on the periodic statement, this information may be included.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-c-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Additional information; disclosures required by other laws. Nothing in § 1026.41 prohibits a servicer from including additional information or combining disclosures required by other laws with the disclosures required by this subpart, unless such prohibition is expressly set forth in this subpart, or other applicable law.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-c-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Electronic distribution. The periodic statement may be provided electronically if the consumer agrees. The consumer must give affirmative consent to receive statements electronically. If statements are provided electronically, the creditor, assignee, or servicer may send a notification that a consumer's statement is available, with a link to where the statement can be accessed, in place of the statement itself.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-c-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Presumed consent. Any consumer who is currently receiving disclosures for any account (for example, a mortgage or checking account) electronically from their servicer shall be deemed to have consented to receiving e-statements in place of paper statements.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp
interpParagraph.title: 20(c) Rate adjustments with a corresponding change in payment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Creditors, assignees, and servicers. Creditors, assignees, and servicers that own either the applicable adjustable-rate mortgage or the applicable mortgage servicing rights or both are subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c). CCreditors, assignees, and servicers are also subject to the requirements of any provision of subpart C that governs § 1026.20(c). For example, the form requirements of § 1026.17(a) apply to § 1026.20(c) disclosures and thus, assignees and servicers, as well as creditors, are subject to those requirements. While creditors, assignees, and servicers are all subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c), they may decide among themselves which of them will provide the required disclosures.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Loan modifications. Under § 1026.20(c), the interest rate adjustment disclosures are required only for interest rate adjustments occurring pursuant to the loan contract. Accordingly, creditors, assignees, and servicers need not provide the disclosures for interest rate adjustments occurring in loan modifications made for loss mitigation purposes. Subsequent interest rate adjustments resulting in a corresponding payment change occurring pursuant to the modified loan contract, however, are subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Conversions. In addition to the disclosures required for interest rate adjustments under an adjustable-rate mortgage, § 1026.20(c) also requires the disclosures for an ARM converting to a fixed-rate transaction when the conversion changes the interest rate and results in a corresponding payment change. When an open-end account converts to a closed-end adjustable-rate mortgage, the § 1026.20(c) disclosure is not required until the implementation of an interest rate adjustment post-conversion that results in a corresponding payment change. For example, for an open-end account that converts to a closed-end 3/1 hybrid ARM, i.e., an ARM with a fixed rate of interest for the first three years after which the interest rate adjusts annually, the first § 1026.20(c) disclosure would not be required until three years after the conversion, and only if that first adjustment resulted in a payment change.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: In general. An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.20(c)(1)(i), is a variable-rate transaction as that term is used in subpart C, except as distinguished by comment § 1026.20(c)(1)(ii)-3. The requirements of this section are not limited to transactions financing the initial acquisition of the consumer's principal dwelling.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Short-term ARMs. Under § 1026.20(c)(1)(ii), construction, home improvement, bridge, and other loans with terms of one year or less are not subject to the requirements in § 1026.20(c). In determining the term of a construction loan that may be permanently financed by the same creditor or assignee, the creditor or assignee may treat the construction and the permanent phases as separate transactions with distinct terms to maturity or as a single combined transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: First new payment due within 210 days after consummation. Section 1026.20(c) disclosures are not required if the first payment at the adjusted level is due within 210 days after consummation, when the new interest rate disclosed at consummation pursuant to § 1026.20(d) is not an estimate. For example, the creditor, assignee, or servicer would not be required to provide the disclosures required by § 1026.20(c) for the first time an ARM interest rate adjusts if the first payment at the adjusted level was due 120 days after consummation and the adjusted interest rate disclosed at consummation pursuant to § 1026.20(d) was not an estimate.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Non-adjustable-rate mortgages. The following transactions, if structured as fixed-rate and not as adjustable-rate mortgages based on an index or formula, are not subject to § 1026.20(c):

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: Shared-equity or shared-appreciation mortgages;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: Price-level adjusted or other indexed mortgages that have a fixed rate of interest but provide for periodic adjustments to payments and the loan balance to reflect changes in an index measuring prices or inflation;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: Graduated-payment mortgages or step-rate transactions;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-iv
interpParagraph.content: Renewable balloon-payment instruments; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-v
interpParagraph.content: Preferred-rate loans.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Timing. The requirement that § 1026.20(c) disclosures be provided to consumers within a certain timeframe means that the creditor, assignee, or servicer must deliver the notice or place it in the mail within that timeframe, excluding any grace or courtesy periods. The requirement that the § 1026.20(c) disclosures must be provided between 25 and 120 days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due for frequently-adjusting ARMs, applies to ARMs that adjust regularly at a maximum of every 60 days.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Current and new interest rates. The current interest rate is the interest rate that applies on the date the disclosure is provided to the consumer. The new interest rate is the actual interest rate that will apply on the date of the adjustment. The new interest rate is used to determine the new payment. The “new interest rate” has the same meaning as the “adjusted interest rate.” The requirements of § 1026.20(c)(2)(ii)(A) do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from rounding the interest rate, pursuant to the requirements of the ARM contract.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iv-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Rate limits and foregone interest rate increases. Interest rate carryover, or foregone interest rate increases, is the amount of interest rate increase foregone at any ARM interest rate adjustment that, subject to rate caps, can be added to future interest rate adjustments to increase, or to offset decreases in, the rate determined by using the index or formula. The disclosures required by § 1026.20(c)(2)(iv) regarding foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-B-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Application of previously foregone interest rate increases. The disclosures regarding the application of previously foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Prepayment penalty. The creditor, assignee, or servicer of an ARM with no prepayment penalty, as that term is used in § 1026.20(c)(2)(vii), may decide to exclude the prepayment section from the § 1026.20(c) disclosure, retain the prepayment section and insert after the heading “None” or other indication that there is no prepayment penalty, or indicate there is no prepayment penalty in some other manner. See also comment 1.vi to Appendices G and H—Open-End and Closed-End Model Forms and Clauses.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-3-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Format of disclosures. The requirements of § 1026.20(c)(3)(i) and (ii) to provide the§ 1026.20(c) disclosures in the same order as, and with headings and format substantially similar to, the model and sample forms do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from modifying the disclosures to accommodate particular consumer circumstances or transactions not addressed by the forms. For example, in the case of a consumer bankruptcy or under certain State laws, the creditor, assignee, or servicer may modify the forms to remove language regarding personal liability. Creditors, assignees, and servicers providing the required notice to a consumer whose ARM is converting to a fixed-rate mortgage, may modify the model language to explain that the interest rate will no longer adjust. Creditors, assignees, and servicers electing to provide consumers with interest rate notices in cases where the interest rate adjusts without a corresponding change in payment may modify the forms to fit that circumstance. A payment-option ARM, which is an ARM permitting consumers to choose among several different payment options for each billing period, is an example of a loan that may require modification of the § 1026.20(c) model and sample forms. See appendix H-30(C) for an example of an allocation table for a payment-option loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a
paragraph.title: General rule
paragraph.content: General rule —

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-1-i
paragraph.title: Consideration of ability to pay.
paragraph.content: Consideration of ability to pay. A <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> must not open a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account for a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> under an open-end (not home-secured) <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> plan, or increase any <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit applicable to such account, unless the <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> considers the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s ability to make the required minimum periodic payments under the terms of the account based on the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets and the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-1-ii
paragraph.title: Reasonable policies and procedures.
paragraph.content: Reasonable policies and procedures. <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">Card issuers</ref> must establish and maintain reasonable written policies and procedures to consider the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s ability to make the required minimum payments under the terms of the account based on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets and a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current obligations. Reasonable policies and procedures include treating any income and assets to which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has a reasonable expectation of access as the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets, or limiting consideration of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s independent income and assets. Reasonable policies and procedures also include consideration of at least one of the following: The ratio of debt obligations to income; the ratio of debt obligations to assets; or the income the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have after paying debt obligations. It would be unreasonable for a <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> not to review any information about a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets and current obligations, or to issue a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> who does not have any income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2
paragraph.title: Minimum periodic payments
paragraph.content: Minimum periodic payments —

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-i
paragraph.title: Reasonable method.
paragraph.content: Reasonable method. For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-51-a-1" reftype="internal">(a)(1)</ref> of this section, a <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> must use a reasonable method for estimating the minimum periodic payments the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> would be required to pay under the terms of the account.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii
paragraph.title: Safe harbor.
paragraph.content: Safe harbor. A <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> complies with paragraph <ref target="1026-51-a-2-i" reftype="internal">(a)(2)(i)</ref> of this section if it estimates required minimum periodic payments using the following method:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> assumes utilization, from the first day of the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>, of the full <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> line that the issuer is considering offering to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> uses a minimum payment formula employed by the issuer for the product the issuer is considering offering to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> or, in the case of an existing account, the minimum payment formula that currently applies to that account, provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B-1
paragraph.content: If the applicable minimum payment formula includes interest charges, the <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> estimates those charges using an interest rate that the issuer is considering offering to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for purchases or, in the case of an existing account, the interest rate that currently applies to purchases; and

paragraph.label: 1026-51-a-2-ii-B-2
paragraph.content: If the applicable minimum payment formula includes mandatory fees, the <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> must assume that such fees have been charged to the account.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b
paragraph.title: Rules affecting young consumers
paragraph.content: Rules affecting young <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref>—

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-1
paragraph.title: Applications from young consumers.
paragraph.content: Applications from young <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref>. A <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> may not open a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account under an open-end (not home-secured) <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> plan for a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> less than 21 years old, unless the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has submitted a written application and the <ref target="1026-2-a-7" reftype="term">card issuer</ref> has:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-1-i
paragraph.content: Financial information indicating the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has an independent ability to make the required minimum periodic payments on the proposed extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> in connection with the account; or<ref target="1026-51-a" reftype="internal"></ref>

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: A signed agreement of a cosigner, guarantor, or joint applicant who is at least 21 years old to be either secondarily liable for any debt on the account incurred by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> before the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has attained the age of 21 or jointly liable with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for any debt on the account; and

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: Financial information indicating such cosigner, guarantor, or joint applicant has the ability to make the required minimum periodic payments on such debts, consistent with paragraph (a) of this <ref target="1026-51-a" reftype="internal">sec</ref>tion.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-2
paragraph.title: Credit line increases for young consumers.
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> line increases for young <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref>. <ref target="1026-51-b-1-ii" reftype="internal"></ref>

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-2-i
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account has been opened pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-51-b-1-i" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(i)</ref> of this section, no increase in the <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit may be made on such account before the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> attains the age of 21 unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-2-i-A
paragraph.content: At the time of the contemplated increase, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has an independent ability to make the required minimum periodic payments on the increased limit consistent with paragraph <ref target="1026-51-b-1-i" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(i)</ref> of this section; or

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-2-i-B
paragraph.content: A cosigner, guarantor, or joint applicant who is at least 21 years old agrees in writing to assume liability for any debt incurred on the account, consistent with paragraph <ref target="1026-51-b-1-ii" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(ii)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-51-b-2-ii
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account has been opened pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-51-b-1-ii" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(ii)</ref> of this section, no increase in the <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit may be made on such account before the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> attains the age of 21 unless the cosigner, guarantor, or joint accountholder who assumed liability at account opening agrees in writing to assume liability on the increase.

paragraph.label: 1026-17-c-1
paragraph.content: The disclosures shall reflect the terms of the legal obligation between the parties.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-B-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Application of previously foregone interest rate increases. The disclosures regarding the application of previously foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii
paragraph.content: Partial payments. Any servicer that retains a partial payment, meaning any payment less than a periodic payment, in a suspense or unapplied funds account shall:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: Disclose to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> the total amount of funds held in such suspense or unapplied funds account on the periodic statement as required by § <ref target="1026-41-d-3" reftype="internal">1026.41(d)(3)</ref>, if a periodic statement is required; and

paragraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: On accumulation of sufficient funds to cover a periodic payment in any suspense or unapplied funds account, treat such funds as a periodic payment received in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-36-c-1-i" reftype="internal">(c)(1)(i)</ref> of this section.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-iii
interpParagraph.content: Graduated-payment mortgages or step-rate transactions;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-ii-Interp-1-iii
interpParagraph.content: Hold the payment in a suspense or unapplied funds account. If the payment is held in a suspense or unapplied funds account, this fact must be reflected on future periodic statements, in accordance with § 1026.41(d)(3). When sufficient funds accumulate to cover a periodic payment, as defined in § 1026.36(c)(1)(i), they must be treated as a periodic payment received in accordance with § 1026.36(c)(1)(i).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-3-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Person acting on behalf of the consumer. For purposes of § 1026.36(c)(3), a person acting on behalf of the consumer may include the consumer's representative, such as an attorney representing the individual, a non-profit consumer counseling or similar organization, or a creditor with which the consumer is refinancing and which requires the payoff statement to complete the refinancing. A creditor, assignee or servicer may take reasonable measures to verify the identity of any person acting on behalf of the consumer and to obtain the consumer's authorization to release information to any such person before the “reasonable time” period begins to run.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-3-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Payment requirements. The creditor, assignee or servicer may specify reasonable requirements for making payoff requests, such as requiring requests to be directed to a mailing address, email address, or fax number specified by the creditor, assignee or servicer or any other reasonable requirement or method. If the consumer does not follow these requirements, a longer timeframe for responding to the request would be reasonable.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-3-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Accuracy of payoff statements. Payoff statements must be accurate when issued.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-xi
paragraph.content: The Web site to access either the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> list or the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations, the HUD toll-free telephone number to access the HUD list of homeownership counselors and counseling organizations, and the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> Web site to access contact information for <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> housing finance authorities (as defined in § 1301 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1989).

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iii
paragraph.content: An explanation of how the interest rate is determined, including:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: The specific index or formula used in making interest rate adjustments and a source of information about the index or formula; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iii-B
paragraph.content: The type and amount of any adjustment to the index, including any margin and an explanation that the margin is the addition of a certain number of percentage points to the index, and any application of previously foregone interest rate increases from past interest rate adjustments.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a
paragraph.title: Refinancings.
paragraph.content: Refinancings. A refinancing occurs when an existing obligation that was subject to this subpart is satisfied and replaced by a new obligation undertaken by the same <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. A refinancing is a new transaction requiring new disclosures to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. The new finance charge shall include any unearned portion of the old finance charge that is not credited to the existing obligation. The following shall not be treated as a refinancing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-1
paragraph.content: A renewal of a single payment obligation with no change in the original terms.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-2
paragraph.content: A reduction in the annual percentage rate with a corresponding change in the payment schedule.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-3
paragraph.content: An agreement involving a court proceeding.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-4
paragraph.content: A change in the payment schedule or a change in collateral requirements as a result of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s default or delinquency, unless the rate is increased, or the new amount financed exceeds the unpaid balance plus earned finance charge and premiums for continuation of insurance of the types described in § <ref target="1026-4-d" reftype="internal">1026.4(d)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-5
paragraph.content: The renewal of optional insurance purchased by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> and added to an existing transaction, if disclosures relating to the initial purchase were provided as required by this subpart.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b
paragraph.title: Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Assumptions. An assumption occurs when a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> expressly agrees in writing with a subsequent <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> to accept that <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> as a primary obligor on an existing <ref target="1026-2-a-24" reftype="term">residential mortgage transaction</ref>. Before the assumption occurs, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> shall make new disclosures to the subsequent <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, based on the remaining obligation. If the finance charge originally imposed on the existing obligation was an add-on or discount finance charge, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> need only disclose:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-1
paragraph.content: The unpaid balance of the obligation assumed.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-2
paragraph.content: The total charges imposed by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> in connection with the assumption.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-3
paragraph.content: The information required to be disclosed under § <ref target="1026-18-k" reftype="internal">1026.18(k)</ref>, <ref target="1026-18-l" reftype="internal">(l)</ref>, <ref target="1026-18-m" reftype="internal">(m)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-18-n" reftype="internal">(n)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-4
paragraph.content: The annual percentage rate originally imposed on the obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-5
paragraph.content: The payment schedule under § <ref target="1026-18-g" reftype="internal">1026.18(g)</ref> and the total of payments under § <ref target="1026-18-h" reftype="internal">1026.18(h)</ref> based on the remaining obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c
paragraph.title: Variable-rate adjustments.
paragraph.content: Rate adjustments with a corresponding change in payment. Th<ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">e c</ref><ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, assignee, or servicer of an adjustable-rate mortgage shall provide <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> with disclosures, as described in this paragraph (c), in connection w<ref target="1026-19-b" reftype="internal">ith the ad</ref>justment of interest rates pursuant to the loan contract that results in a corresponding adjustment to the payment. To the extent that other provisions of this subpart C govern the disclosures required by this paragraph (c), those provisions apply to assignees and servicers as well as to <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref>. The disclosures required by this paragraph (c) also shall be provided for an interest rate adjustment resulting from the conversion of an adjustable-rate mortgage to a fixed-rate transaction, if that interest rate adjustment results in a corresponding payment change.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1
paragraph.content: Coverage.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-20-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref>, an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> in which the annual percentage rate may increase after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii
paragraph.title: Exemptions.
paragraph.content: Exemptions. The requirements of this paragraph <ref target="1026-20-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref> do not apply to:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-A
paragraph.content: ARMs with terms of one year or less; or

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-B
paragraph.content: The first interest rate adjustment to an ARM if the first payment at the adjusted level is due within 210 days after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> and the new interest rate disclosed at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> pursuant to § <ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">1026.20(d)</ref> was not an estimate.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2
paragraph.content: Timing and content. Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (c)(2) of this section, the disclosures required by this paragraph (c) shall be provided to <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> at least 60, but no more than 120, days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due. The disclosures shall be provided to <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> at least 25, but no more than 120, days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due for ARMs with uniformly scheduled interest rate adjustments occurring every 60 days or more frequently and for ARMs originated prior to January 10, 2015 in which the loan contract requires the adjusted interest rate and payment to be calculated based on the index figure available as of a date that is less than 45 days prior to the adjustment date. The disclosures shall be provided to <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> as soon as practicable, but not less than 25 days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due, for the first adjustment to an ARM if it occurs within 60 days of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> and the new interest rate disclosed at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> pursuant to § 1026.20(d) was an estimate. The disclosures required by this paragraph (c) shall include:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i
paragraph.content: A statement providing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-A
paragraph.content: An explanation that under the terms of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s adjustable-rate mortgage, the specific time period in which the current interest rate has been in effect is ending and the interest rate and mortgage payment will change;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-B
paragraph.content: The effective date of the interest rate adjustment and when additional future interest rate adjustments are scheduled to occur; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-i-C
paragraph.content: Any other changes to loan terms, features, or options taking effect on the same date as the interest rate adjustment, such as the expiration of interest-only or payment-option features.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-C
