paragraph.content: Prepayment penalty exception. A mortgage transaction subject to this section may provide for a prepayment penalty (including a refund calculated according to the rule of 78s) otherwise permitted by law if, under the terms of the loan:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-i
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply after the two-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-ii
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-iii
paragraph.content: At <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt payments (including amounts owed under the mortgage) do not exceed 50 percent of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly gross income, as verified in accordance with § <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii" reftype="internal">1026.34(a)(4)(ii)</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-d-7-iv
paragraph.content: The amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5
paragraph.title: Payment calculations.
paragraph.content: Payment calculations. For purposes of determining whether the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payment for a standard mortgage will be materially lower than the monthly payment for the non-standard mortgage, the following provisions shall be used:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i
paragraph.title: Non-standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Non-standard mortgage. For purposes of the comparison conducted pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-2-ii" reftype="internal">(d)(2)(ii)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must calculate the monthly payment for a non-standard mortgage based on substantially equal, monthly, <ref target="1026-43-b-2" reftype="term">fully amortizing payments</ref> of principal and interest using:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-A
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-43-b-3" reftype="term">fully indexed rate</ref> as of a reasonable period of time before or after the date on which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s written application for the standard mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan remaining as of the date on which the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> occurs, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date and the payment due on the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date is made and credited as of that date; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C
paragraph.content: A remaining <ref target="1026-43-b-5" reftype="term">loan amount</ref> that is:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-1
paragraph.content: For an adjustable-rate mortgage under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-1-i-A" reftype="internal">(d)(1)(i)(A)</ref> of this section, the outstanding principal balance as of the date of the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref>, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date and the payment due on the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date is made and credited as of that date;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-2
paragraph.content: For an interest-only loan under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-1-i-B" reftype="internal">(d)(1)(i)(B)</ref> of this section, the outstanding principal balance as of the date of the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref>, assuming all scheduled payments have been made up to the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date and the payment due on the <ref target="1026-43-b-11" reftype="term">recast</ref> date is made and credited as of that date; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-i-C-3
paragraph.content: For a negative amortization loan under paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-1-i-C" reftype="internal">(d)(1)(i)(C)</ref> of this section, the <ref target="1026-43-b-7" reftype="term">maximum loan amount</ref>, determined after adjusting for the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-5-ii
paragraph.title: Standard mortgage.
paragraph.content: Standard mortgage. For purposes of the comparison conducted pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-43-d-2-ii" reftype="internal">(d)(2)(ii)</ref> of this section, the monthly payment for a standard mortgage must be based on substantially equal, monthly, <ref target="1026-43-b-2" reftype="term">fully amortizing payments</ref> based on the maximum interest rate that may apply during the first five years after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-7" reftype="internal">(c)(7)</ref> of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> for purposes of determining the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref>(iv)(A) of this section, together with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payments for all <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref> and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-1
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-32-a-2" reftype="internal">(a)(2)</ref> of this section, the requirements of this section apply to a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction that is secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>, and in which either:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-1-i
paragraph.content: The annual percentage rate at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> will exceed by more than 8 percentage points for first-lien loans, or by more than 10 percentage points for subordinate-lien loans, the yield on Treasury securities having comparable periods of maturity to the loan maturity as of the fifteenth day of the month immediately preceding the month in which the application for the extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> is received by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-1-ii
paragraph.content: The total points and fees payable by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> at or before loan closing will exceed the greater of 8 percent of the total loan amount, or $400; the $400 figure shall be adjusted annually on January 1 by the annual percentage change in the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Price Index that was reported on the preceding June 1.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-2
paragraph.content: This section does not apply to the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-2-i
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-24" reftype="term">residential mortgage transaction</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-2-ii
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-33-a" reftype="term">reverse mortgage transaction</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-33" reftype="internal">1026.33</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-a-2-iii
paragraph.content: An <ref target="1026-2-a-20" reftype="term">open-end credit</ref> plan subject to subpart B of this part.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Fixed rate. For guidance on the meaning of `fixed rate' for purpose of § 1026.41(e)(3), see § 1026.18(s)(7)(iii) and its commentary.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Coupon book. A coupon book is a booklet provided to the consumer with a page for each billing cycle during a set period of time (often covering one year). These pages are designed to be torn off and returned to the servicer with a payment for each billing cycle. Additional information about the loan is often included on or inside the front or back cover, or on filler pages in the coupon book.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Information location. The information required by paragraph (e)(3)(ii) need not be provided on each coupon, but should be provided somewhere in the coupon book. Such information could be located, e.g., on or inside the front or back cover, or on filler pages in the coupon book.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-3-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Outstanding principal balance. Paragraph (e)(3)(ii)(A) requires the information listed in paragraph (d)(7) to be included in the coupon book. Paragraph (d)(7)(i) requires the disclosure of the outstanding principal balance. If the servicer makes use of a coupon book and the exemption in § 1026.41(e)(3), the servicer need only disclose the principal balance at the beginning of the time period covered by the coupon book.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-4
paragraph.title: Total loan amount
paragraph.content: Total loan amount —

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-4-i
paragraph.title: Closed-end credit.
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">Closed-end credit</ref>. The total loan amount for a <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">closed-end credit</ref> transaction is calculated by taking the amount financed, as determined according to § <ref target="1026-18-b" reftype="internal">1026.18(b)</ref>, and deducting any cost listed in § <ref target="1026-32-b-1-iii" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(1)(iii)</ref>, <ref target="1026-32-b-1-iv" reftype="internal">(iv)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-32-b-1-vi" reftype="internal">(vi)</ref> that is both included as points and fees under § <ref target="1026-32-b-1" reftype="internal">1026.32(b)(1)</ref> and financed by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-4-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-5
paragraph.content: Affiliate means any company that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another company, as set forth in the Bank Holding Company <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1956 (<ref target="USC:12-1841" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1841</ref> et seq.).

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-2
paragraph.content: [Reserved]<ref target="USC:12-1841" reftype="external"></ref>

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-3
paragraph.title: Bona fide discount point
paragraph.content: Bona fide discount point —

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-3-i
paragraph.title: Closed-end credit.
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">Closed-end credit</ref>. The term bona fide discount point means an amount equal to 1 percent of the loan amount paid by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> that reduces the interest rate or time-price differential applicable to the transaction based on a calculation that is consistent with established industry practices for determining the amount of reduction in the interest rate or time-price differential appropriate for the amount of discount points paid by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-3-ii
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1
paragraph.content: In connection with a <ref target="1026-2-a-10" reftype="term">closed-end credit</ref><ref target="1026-32-a-1-ii" reftype="internal">d-end cred</ref>it transaction, points and fees means the following fees or charges that are known at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i
paragraph.content: All items included in the finance charge un<ref target="1026-4-a" reftype="internal">der § 102</ref>6.4(a<ref target="1026-4-b" reftype="internal">) and (b)</ref>, except that the following items are excluded:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-A
paragraph.content: Interest or the time-price differential;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-B
paragraph.content: Any premium or other charge imposed in connection with any Federal or <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> agency program for any guaranty or insurance that protects the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> against the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s default or other <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> loss;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C
paragraph.content: For any guaranty or insurance that protects the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> against the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s default or other <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> loss and that is not in connection with any Federal or <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> agency program:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-1
paragraph.content: If the premium or other charge is payable after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, the entire amount of such premium or other charge; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-C-2
paragraph.content: If the premium or other charge is payable at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, the portion of any such premium or other charge that is not in excess of the amount payable under policies in effect at the time of origination under section 203(c)(2)(A) of the National Housing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (<ref target="USC:12-1709" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1709</ref>(c)(2)(A)), provided that the premium or charge is required to be refundable on a pro rata basis and the refund is automatically issued upon notification of the satisfaction of the underlying mortgage loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-D
paragraph.content: Any bona fide third-party charge not retained by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">loan originator</ref>, or an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of either, unless the charge is required to be included in points and fees under paragraph <ref target="1026-32-b-1-i-C" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(i)(C)</ref>, <ref target="1026-32-b-1-iii" reftype="internal">(iii)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-32-b-1-iv" reftype="internal">(iv)</ref> of this section;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E
paragraph.content: Up to two bona fide discount points paid by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in connection with the transaction, if the interest rate without any discount does not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E-1
paragraph.content: The average prime offer rate, as defined in § <ref target="1026-35-a-2" reftype="internal">1026.35(a)(2)</ref>, by more than one percentage point; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-E-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-32-a-1-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(1)(ii)</ref> of this section, for transactions that are secured by personal property, the average rate for a loan insured under Title I of the National Housing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (<ref target="USC:12-1702" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1702</ref> et seq.) by more than one percentage point; and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F
paragraph.content: If no discount points have been excluded under paragraph <ref target="1026-32-b-1-i-E" reftype="internal">(b)(1)(i)(E)</ref> of this section, then up to one bona fide discount point paid by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in connection with the transaction, if the interest rate without any discount does not exceed:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F-1
paragraph.content: The average prime offer rate, as defined in § <ref target="1026-35-a-2" reftype="internal">1026.35(a)(2)</ref>, by more than two percentage points; or

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-i-F-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of paragraph <ref target="1026-32-a-1-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(1)(ii)</ref> of this section, for transactions that are secured by personal property, the average rate for a loan insured under Title I of the National Housing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (<ref target="USC:12-1702" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1702</ref> et seq.) by more than two percentage points;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-ii
paragraph.content: All <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> paid directly or indirectly by a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> or <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> to a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">loan originator</ref>, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), that can be attributed to that transaction at the time the interest rate is set;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii
paragraph.content: All items listed in § <ref target="1026-4-c-7" reftype="internal">1026.4(c)(7)</ref> (other than amounts held for future payment of taxes), unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-A
paragraph.content: The charge is reasonable;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-B
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives no direct or indirect <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> in connection with the charge; and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iii-C
paragraph.content: The charge is not paid to an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv
paragraph.content: Premiums or other charges payable at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> for any <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> life, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> disability, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> unemployment, or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> property insurance, or any other life, accident, health, or loss-of-income insurance for which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> is a beneficiary, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract;

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-v
paragraph.content: The maximum prepayment penalty, as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-32-b-6-i" reftype="internal">(b)(6)(i)</ref> of this section, that may be charged or collected under the terms of the mortgage loan; and

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-vi
paragraph.content: The total prepayment penalty, as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-32-b-6-i" reftype="internal">(b)(6)(i)</ref> of this section, incurred by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> refinances the existing mortgage loan with the current holder of the existing loan, a servicer acting on behalf of the current holder, or an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of either.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref>, an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> in which the annual percentage rate may increase after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv
paragraph.content: Premiums or other charges payable at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> for any <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> life, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> disability, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> unemployment, or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> property insurance, or any other life, accident, health, or loss-of-income insurance for which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> is a beneficiary, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Loans obtained by merger or acquisition. Any mortgage loans obtained by a servicer or an affiliate as part of a merger or acquisition, or as part of the acquisition of all of the assets or liabilities of a branch office of a lender, should be considered mortgage loans for which the servicer or an affiliate is the creditor to which the mortgage loan is initially payable. A branch office means either an office of a depository institution that is approved as a branch by a Federal or State supervisory agency or an office of a for-profit mortgage lending institution (other than a depository institution) that takes applications from the public for mortgage loans.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Application of evaluation threshold. The following examples demonstrate when a servicer either is considered or is no longer considered a small servicer:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: A servicer that begins servicing more than 5,000 mortgage loans on October 1, and services more than 5,000 mortgage loans as of January 1 of the following year, would no longer be considered a small servicer on April 1 of that following year.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: A servicer that begins servicing more than 5,000 mortgage loans on February 1, and services more than 5,000 mortgage loans as of January 1 of the following year, would no longer be considered a small servicer on January 1 of that following year.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-e-4-iii-Interp-2-iii
interpParagraph.content: A servicer that begins servicing more than 5,000 mortgage loans on February 1, but services less than 5,000 mortgage loans as of January 1 of the following year, is considered a small servicer for that following year.

paragraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-i
paragraph.content: The total of all payments received since the last statement, including a breakdown showing the amount, if any, that was applied to principal, interest, escrow, fees and charges, and the amount, if any, sent to any suspense or unapplied funds account; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-3-ii
paragraph.content: The disclosures required by paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d-2-i" reftype="internal">(d)(2)(i)</ref> of this section shall appear outside of and above the table required in paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d-3-i" reftype="internal">(d)(3)(i)</ref> of this section; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-41-d-3-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Suppose a payment of $1,000 is due, but the consumer sends in only $600 on January 1, which is held in a suspense account. Further assume there are no fees charged on this account. Assuming there are no other funds in the suspense account, the January statement should reflect: Unapplied funds since last statement—$600. Unapplied funds YTD—$600.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i
paragraph.content: For purposes of this section, the term “loan originator” means a <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> who, in expectation of direct or indirect <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> or other monetary gain or for direct or indirect <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> or other monetary gain, performs any of the following activities: takes an application, offers, arranges, assists a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> in obtaining or applying to obtain, negotiates, or otherwise obtains or makes an extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> for another <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref>; or through advertising or other means of communication represents to the public that such <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> can or will perform any of these activities. The term “loan originator” includes an employee, agent, or contractor of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or <ref target="1026-36-a-1-iii" reftype="term">loan originator organization</ref> if the employee, agent, or contractor meets this definition. The term “loan originator” includes a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> that engages in loan origination activities if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> does not finance the transaction at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> out of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>'s own resources, including by drawing on a bona fide warehouse line of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> or out of deposits held by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>. All <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> that engage in any of the foregoing loan origination activities are loan originators for purposes of paragraphs <ref target="1026-36-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref> and <ref target="1026-36-g" reftype="internal">(g)</ref> of this section. The term does not include:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-A
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> who does not take a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> application or offer or negotiate <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> terms available from a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, but who performs purely administrative or clerical tasks on behalf of a <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> who does engage in such activities.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-B
paragraph.content: An employee of a manufactured home retailer who does not take a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> application, offer or negotiate <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> terms available from a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, or advise a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> on <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> terms (including rates, fees, and other costs) available from a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-C
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> that performs only real estate brokerage activities and is licensed or registered in accordance with applicable <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref> law, unless such <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">person</ref> is compensated by a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> or by any agent of such <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> for a particular <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction subject to this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-D
paragraph.content: A seller financer that meets the criteria in paragraph <ref target="1026-36-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> or <ref target="1026-36-a-5" reftype="internal">(a)(5)</ref> of this section, as applicable.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-a-1-i-E
paragraph.content: A servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate terms for purposes of renegotiating, modifying, replacing, or subordinating principal of existing mortgages where <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> are behind in their payments, in default, or have a reasonable likelihood of defaulting or falling behind. This exception does not apply, however, to a servicer or servicer's employees, agents, and contractors who offer or negotiate a transaction that constitutes a refinancing under § <ref target="1026-20-a" reftype="internal">1026.20(a)</ref> or obligates a different <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> on the existing debt.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-ii
paragraph.content: All <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> paid directly or indirectly by a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> or <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> to a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">loan originator</ref>, as defined in § 1026.36(a)(1), that can be attributed to that transaction at the time the interest rate is set;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-iii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Payment requirements. The servicer may specify reasonable requirements for making payments in writing, such as requiring that payments be accompanied by the account number or payment coupon; setting a cut-off hour for payment to be received, or setting different hours for payment by mail and payments made in person; specifying that only checks or money orders should be sent by mail; specifying that payment is to be made in U.S. dollars; or specifying one particular address for receiving payments, such as a post office box. The servicer may be prohibited, however, from requiring payment solely by preauthorized electronic fund transfer. See section 913 of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act, 15 U.S.C. 1693k.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-iii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Payment requirements—limitations. Requirements for making payments must be reasonable; it should not be difficult for most consumers to make conforming payments. For example, it would be reasonable to require a cut-off time of 5 p.m. for receipt of a mailed check at the location specified by the servicer for receipt of such check.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-36-c-1-iii-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Implied guidelines for payments. In the absence of specified requirements for making payments, payments may be made at any location where the servicer conducts business; any time during the servicer's normal business hours; and by cash, money order, draft, or other similar instrument in properly negotiable form, or by electronic fund transfer if the servicer and consumer have so agreed.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Current and new interest rates. The current interest rate is the interest rate that applies on the date the disclosure is provided to the consumer. The new interest rate is the actual interest rate that will apply on the date of the adjustment. The new interest rate is used to determine the new payment. The “new interest rate” has the same meaning as the “adjusted interest rate.” The requirements of § 1026.20(c)(2)(ii)(A) do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from rounding the interest rate, pursuant to the requirements of the ARM contract.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Definition. A refinancing is a new transaction requiring a complete new set of disclosures. Whether a refinancing has occurred is determined by reference to whether the original obligation has been satisfied or extinguished and replaced by a new obligation, based on the parties' contract and applicable law. The refinancing may involve the consolidation of several existing obligations, disbursement of new money to the consumer or on the consumer's behalf, or the rescheduling of payments under an existing obligation. In any form, the new obligation must completely replace the prior one.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Changes in the terms of an existing obligation, such as the deferral of individual installments, will not constitute a refinancing unless accomplished by the cancellation of that obligation and the substitution of a new obligation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: A substitution of agreements that meets the refinancing definition will require new disclosures, even if the substitution does not substantially alter the prior credit terms.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Exceptions. A transaction is subject to § 1026.20(a) only if it meets the general definition of a refinancing. Section 1026.20(a)(1) through (5) lists 5 events that are not treated as refinancings, even if they are accomplished by cancellation of the old obligation and substitution of a new one.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Variable-rate.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: If a variable-rate feature was properly disclosed under the regulation, a rate change in accord with those disclosures is not a refinancing. For example, no new disclosures are required when the variable-rate feature is invoked on a renewable balloon-payment mortgage that was previously disclosed as a variable-rate transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: Even if it is not accomplished by the cancellation of the old obligation and substitution of a new one, a new transaction subject to new disclosures results if the creditor either:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3-ii-A
interpParagraph.content: Increases the rate based on a variable-rate feature that was not previously disclosed; or

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3-ii-B
interpParagraph.content: Adds a variable-rate feature to the obligation. A creditor does not add a variable-rate feature by changing the index of a variable-rate transaction to a comparable index, whether the change replaces the existing index or substitutes an index for one that no longer exists.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: If either of the events in paragraph 20(a)-3.ii.A or ii.B occurs in a transaction secured by a principal dwelling with a term longer than one year, the disclosures required under § 1026.19(b) also must be given at that time.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Unearned finance charge. In a transaction involving precomputed finance charges, the creditor must include in the finance charge on the refinanced obligation any unearned portion of the original finance charge that is not rebated to the consumer or credited against the underlying obligation. For example, in a transaction with an add-on finance charge, a creditor advances new money to a consumer in a fashion that extinguishes the original obligation and replaces it with a new one. The creditor neither refunds the unearned finance charge on the original obligation to the consumer nor credits it to the remaining balance on the old obligation. Under these circumstances, the unearned finance charge must be included in the finance charge on the new obligation and reflected in the annual percentage rate disclosed on refinancing. Accrued but unpaid finance charges are included in the amount financed in the new obligation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-Interp-5
interpParagraph.content: Coverage. Section 1026.20(a) applies only to refinancings undertaken by the original creditor or a holder or servicer of the original obligation. A “refinancing” by any other person is a new transaction under the regulation, not a refinancing under this section.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-1-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Renewal. This exception applies both to obligations with a single payment of principal and interest and to obligations with periodic payments of interest and a final payment of principal. In determining whether a new obligation replacing an old one is a renewal of the original terms or a refinancing, the creditor may consider it a renewal even if:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-1-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: Accrued unpaid interest is added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-1-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Changes are made in the terms of renewal resulting from the factors listed in § 1026.17(c)(3).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-1-Interp-1-iii
interpParagraph.content: The principal at renewal is reduced by a curtailment of the obligation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-2-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Annual percentage rate reduction. A reduction in the annual percentage rate with a corresponding change in the payment schedule is not a refinancing. If the annual percentage rate is subsequently increased (even though it remains below its original level) and the increase is effected in such a way that the old obligation is satisfied and replaced, new disclosures must then be made.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-2-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Corresponding change. A corresponding change in the payment schedule to implement a lower annual percentage rate would be a shortening of the maturity, or a reduction in the payment amount or the number of payments of an obligation. The exception in § 1026.20(a)(2) does not apply if the maturity is lengthened, or if the payment amount or number of payments is increased beyond that remaining on the existing transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-3-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Court agreements. This exception includes, for example, agreements such as reaffirmations of debts discharged in bankruptcy, settlement agreements, and post-judgment agreements. (See the commentary to § 1026.2(a)(14) for a discussion of court-approved agreements that are not considered “credit.”)

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-4-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Workout agreements. A workout agreement is not a refinancing unless the annual percentage rate is increased or additional credit is advanced beyond amounts already accrued plus insurance premiums.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-a-5-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Insurance renewal. The renewal of optional insurance added to an existing credit transaction is not a refinancing, assuming that appropriate Truth in Lending disclosures were provided for the initial purchase of the insurance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: General definition.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1-i
interpParagraph.content: An assumption as defined in § 1026.20(b) is a new transaction and new disclosures must be made to the subsequent consumer. An assumption under the regulation requires the following three elements:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1-i-A
interpParagraph.content: A residential mortgage transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1-i-B
interpParagraph.content: An express acceptance of the subsequent consumer by the creditor.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1-i-C
interpParagraph.content: A written agreement.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: The assumption of a nonexempt consumer credit obligation requires no disclosures unless all three elements are present. For example, an automobile dealer need not provide Truth in Lending disclosures to a customer who assumes an existing obligation secured by an automobile. However, a residential mortgage transaction with the elements described in § 1026.20(b) is an assumption that calls for new disclosures; the disclosures must be given whether or not the assumption is accompanied by changes in the terms of the obligation. (See comment 2(a)(24)-5 for a discussion of assumptions that are not considered residential mortgage transactions.)

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Existing residential mortgage transaction. A transaction may be a residential mortgage transaction as to one consumer and not to the other consumer. In that case, the creditor must look to the assuming consumer in determining whether a residential mortgage transaction exists. To illustrate: The original consumer obtained a mortgage to purchase a home for vacation purposes. The loan was not a residential mortgage transaction as to that consumer. The mortgage is assumed by a consumer who will use the home as a principal dwelling. As to that consumer, the loan is a residential mortgage transaction. For purposes of § 1026.20(b), the assumed loan is an “existing residential mortgage transaction” requiring disclosures, if the other criteria for an assumption are met.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Express agreement. Expressly agrees means that the creditor's agreement must relate specifically to the new debtor and must unequivocally accept that debtor as a primary obligor. The following events are not construed to be express agreements between the creditor and the subsequent consumer:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: Approval of creditworthiness.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: Notification of a change in records.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: Mailing of a coupon book to the subsequent consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-3-iv
interpParagraph.content: Acceptance of payments from the new consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Retention of original consumer. The retention of the original consumer as an obligor in some capacity does not prevent the change from being an assumption, provided the new consumer becomes a primary obligor. But the mere addition of a guarantor to an obligation for which the original consumer remains primarily liable does not give rise to an assumption. However, if neither party is designated as the primary obligor but the creditor accepts payment from the subsequent consumer, an assumption exists for purposes of § 1026.20(b).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-5
interpParagraph.content: Status of parties. Section 1026.20(b) applies only if the previous debtor was a consumer and the obligation is assumed by another consumer. It does not apply, for example, when an individual takes over the obligation of a corporation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-6
interpParagraph.content: Disclosures. For transactions that are assumptions within this provision, the creditor must make disclosures based on the “remaining obligation.” For example:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-6-i
interpParagraph.content: The amount financed is the remaining principal balance plus any arrearages or other accrued charges from the original transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-6-ii
interpParagraph.content: If the finance charge is computed from time to time by application of a percentage rate to an unpaid balance, in determining the amount of the finance charge and the annual percentage rate to be disclosed, the creditor should disregard any prepaid finance charges paid by the original obligor, but must include in the finance charge any prepaid finance charge imposed in connection with the assumption.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-6-iii
interpParagraph.content: If the creditor requires the assuming consumer to pay any charges as a condition of the assumption, those sums are prepaid finance charges as to that consumer, unless exempt from the finance charge under § 1026.4. If a transaction involves add-on or discount finance charges, the creditor may make abbreviated disclosures, as outlined in § 1026.20(b)(1) through (5). Creditors providing disclosures pursuant to this section for assumptions of variable-rate transactions secured by the consumer's principal dwelling with a term longer than one year need not provide new disclosures under § 1026.18(f)(2)(ii) or § 1026.19(b). In such transactions, a creditor may disclose the variable-rate feature solely in accordance with § 1026.18(f)(1).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-b-Interp-7
interpParagraph.content: Abbreviated disclosures. The abbreviated disclosures permitted for assumptions of transactions involving add-on or discount finance charges must be made clearly and conspicuously in writing in a form that the consumer may keep. However, the creditor need not comply with the segregation requirement of § 1026.17(a)(1). The terms annual percentage rate and total of payments, when disclosed according to § 1026.20(b)(4) and (5), are not subject to the description requirements of § 1026.18(e) and (h). The term annual percentage rate disclosed under § 1026.20(b)(4) need not be more conspicuous than other disclosures.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp
interpParagraph.title: 20(c) Rate adjustments with a corresponding change in payment.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Creditors, assignees, and servicers. Creditors, assignees, and servicers that own either the applicable adjustable-rate mortgage or the applicable mortgage servicing rights or both are subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c). CCreditors, assignees, and servicers are also subject to the requirements of any provision of subpart C that governs § 1026.20(c). For example, the form requirements of § 1026.17(a) apply to § 1026.20(c) disclosures and thus, assignees and servicers, as well as creditors, are subject to those requirements. While creditors, assignees, and servicers are all subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c), they may decide among themselves which of them will provide the required disclosures.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Loan modifications. Under § 1026.20(c), the interest rate adjustment disclosures are required only for interest rate adjustments occurring pursuant to the loan contract. Accordingly, creditors, assignees, and servicers need not provide the disclosures for interest rate adjustments occurring in loan modifications made for loss mitigation purposes. Subsequent interest rate adjustments resulting in a corresponding payment change occurring pursuant to the modified loan contract, however, are subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(c).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Conversions. In addition to the disclosures required for interest rate adjustments under an adjustable-rate mortgage, § 1026.20(c) also requires the disclosures for an ARM converting to a fixed-rate transaction when the conversion changes the interest rate and results in a corresponding payment change. When an open-end account converts to a closed-end adjustable-rate mortgage, the § 1026.20(c) disclosure is not required until the implementation of an interest rate adjustment post-conversion that results in a corresponding payment change. For example, for an open-end account that converts to a closed-end 3/1 hybrid ARM, i.e., an ARM with a fixed rate of interest for the first three years after which the interest rate adjusts annually, the first § 1026.20(c) disclosure would not be required until three years after the conversion, and only if that first adjustment resulted in a payment change.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: In general. An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.20(c)(1)(i), is a variable-rate transaction as that term is used in subpart C, except as distinguished by comment § 1026.20(c)(1)(ii)-3. The requirements of this section are not limited to transactions financing the initial acquisition of the consumer's principal dwelling.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Short-term ARMs. Under § 1026.20(c)(1)(ii), construction, home improvement, bridge, and other loans with terms of one year or less are not subject to the requirements in § 1026.20(c). In determining the term of a construction loan that may be permanently financed by the same creditor or assignee, the creditor or assignee may treat the construction and the permanent phases as separate transactions with distinct terms to maturity or as a single combined transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: First new payment due within 210 days after consummation. Section 1026.20(c) disclosures are not required if the first payment at the adjusted level is due within 210 days after consummation, when the new interest rate disclosed at consummation pursuant to § 1026.20(d) is not an estimate. For example, the creditor, assignee, or servicer would not be required to provide the disclosures required by § 1026.20(c) for the first time an ARM interest rate adjusts if the first payment at the adjusted level was due 120 days after consummation and the adjusted interest rate disclosed at consummation pursuant to § 1026.20(d) was not an estimate.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Non-adjustable-rate mortgages. The following transactions, if structured as fixed-rate and not as adjustable-rate mortgages based on an index or formula, are not subject to § 1026.20(c):

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-i
interpParagraph.content: Shared-equity or shared-appreciation mortgages;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-ii
interpParagraph.content: Price-level adjusted or other indexed mortgages that have a fixed rate of interest but provide for periodic adjustments to payments and the loan balance to reflect changes in an index measuring prices or inflation;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-iii
interpParagraph.content: Graduated-payment mortgages or step-rate transactions;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-iv
interpParagraph.content: Renewable balloon-payment instruments; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-1-ii-Interp-3-v
interpParagraph.content: Preferred-rate loans.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Timing. The requirement that § 1026.20(c) disclosures be provided to consumers within a certain timeframe means that the creditor, assignee, or servicer must deliver the notice or place it in the mail within that timeframe, excluding any grace or courtesy periods. The requirement that the § 1026.20(c) disclosures must be provided between 25 and 120 days before the first payment at the adjusted level is due for frequently-adjusting ARMs, applies to ARMs that adjust regularly at a maximum of every 60 days.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Current and new interest rates. The current interest rate is the interest rate that applies on the date the disclosure is provided to the consumer. The new interest rate is the actual interest rate that will apply on the date of the adjustment. The new interest rate is used to determine the new payment. The “new interest rate” has the same meaning as the “adjusted interest rate.” The requirements of § 1026.20(c)(2)(ii)(A) do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from rounding the interest rate, pursuant to the requirements of the ARM contract.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iv-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Rate limits and foregone interest rate increases. Interest rate carryover, or foregone interest rate increases, is the amount of interest rate increase foregone at any ARM interest rate adjustment that, subject to rate caps, can be added to future interest rate adjustments to increase, or to offset decreases in, the rate determined by using the index or formula. The disclosures required by § 1026.20(c)(2)(iv) regarding foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-v-B-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Application of previously foregone interest rate increases. The disclosures regarding the application of previously foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(c)(2)(vi) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vi-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-vii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Prepayment penalty. The creditor, assignee, or servicer of an ARM with no prepayment penalty, as that term is used in § 1026.20(c)(2)(vii), may decide to exclude the prepayment section from the § 1026.20(c) disclosure, retain the prepayment section and insert after the heading “None” or other indication that there is no prepayment penalty, or indicate there is no prepayment penalty in some other manner. See also comment 1.vi to Appendices G and H—Open-End and Closed-End Model Forms and Clauses.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-c-3-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Format of disclosures. The requirements of § 1026.20(c)(3)(i) and (ii) to provide the§ 1026.20(c) disclosures in the same order as, and with headings and format substantially similar to, the model and sample forms do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from modifying the disclosures to accommodate particular consumer circumstances or transactions not addressed by the forms. For example, in the case of a consumer bankruptcy or under certain State laws, the creditor, assignee, or servicer may modify the forms to remove language regarding personal liability. Creditors, assignees, and servicers providing the required notice to a consumer whose ARM is converting to a fixed-rate mortgage, may modify the model language to explain that the interest rate will no longer adjust. Creditors, assignees, and servicers electing to provide consumers with interest rate notices in cases where the interest rate adjusts without a corresponding change in payment may modify the forms to fit that circumstance. A payment-option ARM, which is an ARM permitting consumers to choose among several different payment options for each billing period, is an example of a loan that may require modification of the § 1026.20(c) model and sample forms. See appendix H-30(C) for an example of an allocation table for a payment-option loan.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Creditors, assignees, and servicers. Creditors, assignees, and servicers that own either the applicable adjustable-rate mortgage or the applicable mortgage servicing rights or both are subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(d). Creditors, assignees, and servicers are also subject to the requirements of any provision of subpart C that governs § 1026.20(d). For example, the form requirements of § 1026.17(a) apply to § 1026.20(d) disclosures and thus, assignees and servicers, as well as creditors, are subject to those requirements. While creditors, assignees, and servicers are all subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(d), they may decide among themselves which of them will provide the required disclosures.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Loan modifications. Under § 1026.20(d), the interest rate adjustment disclosures are required only for the initial interest rate adjustment occurring pursuant to the loan contract. Accordingly, creditors, assignees, and servicers need not provide the disclosures for interest rate adjustments occurring in loan modifications made for loss mitigation purposes. The initial interest rate adjustment occurring pursuant to the modified loan contract, however, is subject to the requirements of § 1026.20(d).

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-Interp-3
interpParagraph.content: Timing and form of initial rate adjustment. The requirement that § 1026.20(d) disclosures be provided in writing, separate and distinct from all other correspondence, means that the initial ARM interest rate adjustment notice must be provided to consumers as a separate document but may, in the case of mailing the disclosure, be in the same envelope with other material and, in the case of emailing the disclosure, be a separate attachment from other attachments in the same email. The requirement that the disclosures be provided to consumers between 210 and 240 days “before the first payment at the adjusted level is due” means the creditor, assignee, or servicer must deliver the notice or place it in the mail between 210 and 240 days prior to the due date, excluding any grace or courtesy periods, of the first payment calculated using the adjusted interest rate.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-Interp-4
interpParagraph.content: Conversions. When an open-end account converts to a closed-end adjustable-rate mortgage, the § 1026.20(d) disclosure is not required until the implementation of the initial interest rate adjustment post-conversion. For example, for an open-end account that converts to a closed-end 3/1 hybrid ARM, i.e., an ARM with a fixed rate of interest for the first three years after which the interest rate adjusts annually, the § 1026.20(d) disclosure would not be required until three years after the conversion when the interest rate adjusts for the first time.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: In general. An adjustable-rate mortgage, as defined in § 1026.20(d)(1)(i), is a variable-rate transaction as that term is used in subpart C, except as distinguished by comment § 1026.20(d)(1)(ii)-2. The requirements of this section are not limited to transactions financing the initial acquisition of the consumer's principal dwelling.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Short-term ARMs. Under § 1026.20(d)(1)(ii), construction, home improvement, bridge, and other loans with terms of one year or less are not subject to the requirements in § 1026.20(d). In determining the term of a construction loan that may be permanently financed by the same creditor or assignee, the creditor or assignee may treat the construction and the permanent phases as separate transactions with distinct terms to maturity or as a single combined transaction.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Non-adjustable-rate mortgages. The following transactions, if structured as fixed-rate and not as adjustable-rate mortgages based on an index or formula, are not subject to § 1026.20(d):

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: Shared-equity or shared-appreciation mortgages;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Price-level adjusted or other indexed mortgages that have a fixed rate of interest but provide for periodic adjustments to payments and the loan balance to reflect changes in an index measuring prices or inflation;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-iii
interpParagraph.content: Graduated-payment mortgages or step-rate transactions;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-iv
interpParagraph.content: Renewable balloon-payment instruments; and

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-ii-Interp-2-v
interpParagraph.content: Preferred-rate loans.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Date of the disclosure. The date that must appear on the disclosure is the date the creditor, assignee, or servicer generates the notice to be provided to the consumer.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-iii-A-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Current and new interest rates. The current interest rate is the interest rate that applies on the date of the disclosure. The new interest rate is the interest rate used to calculate the new payment and may be an estimate pursuant to § 1026.20(d)(2). The new payment, if calculated from an estimated new interest rate, will also be an estimate. The “new interest rate” has the same meaning as the “adjusted interest rate.” The requirements of § 1026.20(d)(2)(iii)(A) do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from rounding the interest rate, pursuant to the requirements of the ARM contract.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-v-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Rate limits and foregone interest rate increases. Interest rate carryover, or foregone interest rate increases, is the amount of interest rate increase foregone at the first ARM interest rate adjustment that, subject to rate caps, can be added to future interest rate adjustments to increase, or to offset decreases in, the rate determined by using the index or formula. The disclosures required by § 1026.20(d)(2)(v) regarding foregone interest rate increases apply only to transactions permitting interest rate carryover.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Amortization statement. For ARMs requiring the payment of interest only, such as interest-only loans, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers all of the interest but none of the principal, and therefore will not reduce the loan balance. For negatively-amortizing ARMs, § 1026.20(d)(2)(vii) requires a statement that the new payment covers only part of the interest and none of the principal, and therefore the unpaid interest will be added to the principal balance.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-vii-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Amortization payment. Disclosure of the payment needed to amortize fully the outstanding balance at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term is required only when negative amortization occurs as a result of the interest rate adjustment. The disclosure is not required simply because a loan has interest-only or partially-amortizing payments. For example, an ARM with a five-year term and payments based on a longer amortization schedule, in which the final payment will equal the periodic payment plus the remaining unpaid balance, does not require disclosure of the payment necessary to amortize fully the loan in the remainder of the five-year term. A disclosure is also not required when the new payment is sufficient to prevent negative amortization but the final loan payment will be a different amount due to rounding.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-2-viii-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Prepayment penalty. The creditor, assignee, or servicer of an ARM with no prepayment penalty, as that term is used in § 1026.20(d)(2)(viii), may decide to exclude the prepayment section from the § 1026.20(d) disclosure, retain the prepayment section and insert after the heading “None” or other indication that there is no prepayment penalty, or indicate there is no prepayment penalty in some other manner. See also comment to Appendices G and H—Open-End and Closed-End Model Forms and Clauses—1.vi.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-20-d-3-i-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Format of disclosures. The requirements of § 1026.20(d)(3)(i) and (iii) to provide the§ 1026.20(d) disclosures in the same order as, and with headings and format substantially similar to, the model and sample forms do not preclude creditors, assignees, and servicers from modifying the disclosures to accommodate particular consumer circumstances or transactions not addressed by the forms. For example, in the case of a consumer bankruptcy or under certain State laws, the creditor, assignee, or servicer may modify the forms to remove language regarding personal liability. A payment-option ARM, which is an ARM permitting consumers to choose among several different payment options for each billing period, is an example of a loan that may require modification of the § 1026.20(d) model and sample forms. See appendix H-30(C) for an example of an allocation table for a payment-option loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-B
paragraph.content: A county is “underserved” during a calendar year if, according to Home Mortgage Disclosure <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (HMDA) data for the preceding calendar year, no more than two <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> extended covered transactions, as defined in § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, five or more times in the county. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> to determine whether a county qualifies as “underserved” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">States</ref> Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-3-i
paragraph.content: Except for the disclosures required by paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d-2-i" reftype="internal">(d)(2)(i)</ref> of this section, the disclosures required by this paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref> shall be provided in the form of a table and in the same order as, and with headings and format substantially similar to, forms <ref target="1026-H-4(D)(3)" reftype="internal">H-4(D)(3)</ref> and (4) in appendix <ref target="1026-H" reftype="internal">H</ref> to this part;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-iv
paragraph.content: Any limits on the interest rate or payment increases at each interest rate adjustment and over the life of the loan, as applicable, including the extent to which such limits result in the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>, assignee, or servicer foregoing any increase in the interest rate and the earliest date that such foregone interest rate increases may apply to future interest rate adjustments, subject to those limits.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. Extend <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> subject to § <ref target="1026-32" reftype="internal">1026.32</ref> to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> based on the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s collateral without regard to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>, including the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current and reasonably expected income, employment, assets other than the collateral, current obligations, and mortgage-related obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-i
paragraph.title: Mortgage-related obligations.
paragraph.content: Mortgage-related obligations. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref>, mortgage-related obligations are expected property taxes, premiums for mortgage-related insurance required by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> as set forth in § <ref target="1026-35-b-3-i" reftype="internal">1026.35(b), and </ref>similar expenses.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii
paragraph.title: Verification of repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Verification of repayment ability. Under this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as follows:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify amounts of income or assets that it relies on to determine repayment ability, including expected income or assets, by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s Internal Revenue Service Form W-2, tax returns, payroll receipts, financial institution records, or other third-party documents that provide reasonably reliable evidence of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii-A" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)(A)</ref>, a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> has not violated paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)</ref> if the amounts of income and assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> relied upon in determining repayment ability are not materially greater than the amounts of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income or assets that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> could have verified pursuant to paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii-A" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)(A)</ref> at the time the loan was consummated.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii
paragraph.title: Presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Presumption of compliance. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> is presumed to have complied with this paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> with respect to a transaction if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Verifies the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-ii" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(ii)</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-B
paragraph.content: Determines the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability using the largest payment of principal and interest scheduled in the first seven years following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> and taking into account current obligations and mortgage-related obligations as defined in paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4-i" reftype="internal">(a)(4)(i)</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iii-C
paragraph.content: Assesses the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability taking into account at least one of the following: The ratio of total debt obligations to income, or the income the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> will have after paying debt obligations.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv
paragraph.title: Exclusions from presumption of compliance.
paragraph.content: Exclusions from presumption of compliance. Notwithstanding the previous paragraph, no presumption of compliance is available for a transaction for which:

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-A
paragraph.content: The regular periodic payments for the first seven years would cause the principal balance to increase; or

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-iv-B
paragraph.content: The term of the loan is less than seven years and the regular periodic payments when aggregated do not fully amortize the outstanding principal balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-34-a-4-v
paragraph.title: Exemption.
paragraph.content: Exemption. This paragraph <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">(a)(4)</ref> does not apply to temporary or “bridge” loans with terms of twelve months or less, such as a loan to purchase a new <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> where the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> plans to sell a current <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> within twelve months.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: For interest-only or negatively-amortizing payments, the amount of the current and new payment allocated to principal, interest, and taxes and insurance in escrow, as applicable. The current payment allocation disclosed shall be the payment allocation for the last payment prior to the date of the disclosure. The new payment allocation disclosed shall be the expected payment allocation for the first payment for which the new interest rate will apply.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4
paragraph.title: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules
paragraph.content: Qualified mortgage defined—special rules —

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i
paragraph.title: General.
paragraph.content: General. Notwithstanding paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-2" reftype="internal">(e)(2)</ref> of this section, a qualified mortgage is a <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> that satisfies:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-A
paragraph.content: The requirements of paragraphs <ref target="1026-43-e-2-i" reftype="internal">(e)(2)(i)</ref> through <ref target="1026-43-e-2-iii" reftype="internal">(iii)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-i-B
paragraph.content: One or more of the criteria in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii" reftype="internal">(e)(4)(ii)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii
paragraph.title: Eligible loans.
paragraph.content: Eligible loans. A qualified mortgage under this paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4" reftype="internal">(e)(4)</ref> must be one of the following at <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-1
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation operating under the conservatorship or receivership of the Federal Housing Finance Agency pursuant to section 1367(a) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1992 (<ref target="USC:12-4617" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 4617</ref>(a)); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-A-2
paragraph.content: To be purchased or guaranteed by any limited-life regulatory entity succeeding the charter of either the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation pursuant to section 1367(i) of the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1992 (<ref target="USC:12-4617" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 4617</ref>(i));

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-B
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development under the National Housing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> (<ref target="USC:12-1707" reftype="external">12 U.S.C. 1707</ref> et seq.);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-C
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-D
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture pursuant to <ref target="USC:42-1472" reftype="external">42 U.S.C. 1472</ref>(h); or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-ii-E
paragraph.content: A loan that is eligible to be insured by the Rural Housing Service.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii
paragraph.title: Sunset of special rules.
paragraph.content: Sunset of special rules.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-A
paragraph.content: Each respective special rule described in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-B" reftype="internal">(e)(4)(ii)(B)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-C" reftype="internal">(C)</ref>, <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-D" reftype="internal">(D)</ref>, or <ref target="1026-43-e-4-ii-E" reftype="internal">(E)</ref> of this section shall expire on the effective date of a rule issued by each respective agency pursuant to its authority under TILA section 129C(b)(3)(ii) to define a qualified mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-e-4-iii-B
